questions.text: Name the joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone is known as a synchondrosis. Synchondrosis is a type of primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage. In the context of long bones, this joint occurs between the epiphyseal plate (growth plate) and the diaphysis during the development of the bone.

 

The epiphyseal plate is a layer of hyaline cartilage that allows the bone to grow in length. As growth continues, this cartilage eventually undergoes ossification, transforming into bone and thereby eliminating the synchondrosis joint, marking the end of growth in length.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a fibrous joint where bones are connected by a ligament or a sheet of fibrous tissue. It does not involve cartilage and is therefore not applicable to the junction between the epiphysis and diaphysis.

 

Option C. Synarthrosis: Synarthrosis refers to an immovable joint. While synchondrosis could be considered a type of synarthrosis when ossified, it specifically refers to the cartilaginous joint prior to ossification. Thus, this option is less specific and not the correct answer in this context.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Symphysis is a secondary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by fibrocartilage. It is typically found in the midline of the body, such as the pubic symphysis or the intervertebral discs. This type of joint does not describe the connection between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The joint formed between the epiphysis and diaphysis of a long bone during development is a synchondrosis, which is a primary cartilaginous joint composed of hyaline cartilage that eventually ossifies as growth completes.

questions.text: What is the maximum score that can be achieved in the New Ballard Score? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 50 

 

Explanation: 

 

The New Ballard Score (also called the Expanded New Ballard Score) is a clinical assessment tool used to determine gestational age in newborns. It evaluates both neuromuscular and physical maturity criteria. The score consists of six neuromuscular criteria (posture, square window, arm recoil, popliteal angle, scarf sign, and heel to ear) and six physical maturity criteria (skin, lanugo, plantar surface, breast, eye/ear, and genitalia). A total possible range is from -10 to +50 points. Thus, the maximum achievable score is 50, which corresponds to a gestational age of approximately 44 weeks.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 30 - Incorrect. This is below the maximum possible score. A score of 30 would correspond to a gestational age of approximately 36-38 weeks.

 

Option B. 40 - Incorrect. This is below the maximum possible score. A score of 40 would correspond to a gestational age of approximately 40-42 weeks.

 

Option D. 60 - Incorrect. This exceeds the maximum possible score for the New Ballard Score. The highest possible score is 50 points.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The New Ballard Score has a maximum value of 50 points, which corresponds to a post-term infant of approximately 44 weeks gestational age. This scoring system allows for assessment of premature infants as young as 20 weeks gestational age (score of -10).

questions.text: Analyze the pedigree provided. Which mode of inheritance does it suggest? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial inheritance

 

This pedigree shows a pattern consistent with mitochondrial inheritance.

 

Key features supporting this conclusion include:

  • Only females transmit the trait (maternal inheritance pattern).
  • All children (sons and daughters) of affected mothers are affected.
  • No children of affected fathers are affected.
  • The trait appears in every generation via the maternal line only.
  • Male-to-offspring transmission is absent, which is a hallmark of mitochondrial inheritance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal recessive – Incorrect

Autosomal recessive conditions typically show a horizontal pattern (affecting siblings rather than parent-to-child transmission). They often skip generations and require both parents to be carriers. In contrast, this pedigree shows consistent maternal transmission without generational skipping.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant – Incorrect

Autosomal dominant inheritance shows vertical transmission with equal male and female transmission, and affected fathers can pass the trait to their children. However, in this pedigree, affected males do not transmit the trait at all, which is not compatible with autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

Option D. X-linked dominant – Incorrect

X-linked dominant inheritance shows father-to-daughter transmission (all daughters of affected fathers are affected, but sons are not). This pattern is not seen in the pedigree, and males do not transmit the condition, ruling out X-linked dominance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by maternal transmission only. All children of affected mothers inherit the condition, whereas no children of affected fathers are affected, due to the exclusive maternal origin of mitochondrial DNA. Both males and females may be affected, but only females pass on the trait.

choices.text: Network analysis and machinery installed
Equipment ordered and staff training
Work sampling and machinery installed

questions.text: Study the management technique given in the diagram. Identify the technique and find out the critical path. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Network analysis and machinery installed

 

The diagram shows a network analysis technique that includes PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method). When analyzing the two possible paths:

 

  • Path 1: 4 + 2 + 1 + 1 = 8 months total duration
  • Path 2: 2 + 10 + 1 = 13 months total duration The critical path is the longer duration path (13 months), where equipment installation takes the longest time (10 months), making it the most critical component.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Equipment ordered and staff training: Incorrect as these are components but not the critical path which has the longest duration 

 

Option C. Work sampling and machinery installed: Incorrect as this is not a work sampling technique, which is used for observing work activities 

 

Option D. Work sampling and staff training: Incorrect as the diagram shows network analysis, not work sampling

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Network analysis consists of two components:

 

  • PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) - Shows sequence of activities

 

 

CPM (Critical Path Method) - Identifies the longest duration path in the network

choices.text: Oral candidiasis is common with its use.
It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids.
It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase.
It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ciclesonide is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis is common with its use.

 

Ciclesonide is an inhalational corticosteroid used to manage asthma and other respiratory conditions.

 

It is unique among inhaled corticosteroids because it is a "soft steroid" and functions as a prodrug. This means that Ciclesonide is inactive when administered and only becomes active when it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases. This activation in the target site, the bronchial airways, significantly reduces the drug's systemic side effects, including the risk of oral candidiasis, which is common with other inhaled corticosteroids.

 

Because the majority of the drug that deposits in the oropharynx remains inactive, the likelihood of developing oral candidiasis (a common side effect of other inhalational steroids due to local immunosuppression) is significantly lower with Ciclesonide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids: This statement is correct. Due to its activation in the bronchial tree, Ciclesonide has fewer systemic and local side effects compared to other inhalational corticosteroids.

 

Option C. It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase: This is also correct. Ciclesonide remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases.

 

Option D. It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids: This is correct. Ciclesonide is just as effective as other inhalational corticosteroids in managing respiratory conditions such as asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciclesonide, a prodrug inhalational corticosteroid, has a lower risk of causing oral candidiasis compared to other inhalational steroids because it remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is activated by bronchial esterases.

questions.text: According to the Lund-Browder Chart, which body region's surface area percentage remains constant across all age groups? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Arm

 

Explanation: 

 

The Lund-Browder chart is used to calculate the percentage of total body surface area (TBSA) involved in burns and is specifically modified for children to account for the changing body proportions with age. According to this chart, the arm (including both anterior and posterior surfaces) consistently accounts for 9% of the total body surface area regardless of age. This percentage remains constant from birth through adulthood, making it a stable reference point when calculating burn surface area across different age groups.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Head - Incorrect. The head's surface area percentage changes dramatically with age. It accounts for approximately 19% of TBSA in infants but decreases to about 9% in adults as the body grows and proportions change.

 

Option B. Thigh - Incorrect. The thigh's surface area percentage increases with age. In infants, each thigh (anterior and posterior together) accounts for about 5.5% of TBSA, which increases to about 9.5% in adults.

 

Option C. Leg - Incorrect. The leg's surface area percentage also changes with age, increasing slightly from infancy (5%) to adulthood (7%) as the lower extremities become proportionally longer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When using the Lund-Browder chart for burn assessment in pediatric patients, the arm surface area remains constant at 9% throughout all age groups, while head and lower extremity percentages change significantly with age.

choices.text: Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Give MR vaccine + Treat Vit-A deficiency + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Give aspirin for fever + Treat Vit-A deficiency

questions.text: A child has Measles. He presents to OPD at PHC with red congestion of eyes, fever, and coryza. On examination, he has got Bitot spots. Management protocol for this child will be: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency

 

The child presents with classic symptoms of measles (red eyes, fever, coryza) along with Bitot spots indicating Vitamin A deficiency. The management protocol should include:

 

  • Isolation - since measles is highly infectious
  • Symptomatic management - Supportive care includes adequate hydration, fever management and addressing secondary bacterial infections if present.
  • Treatment of Vitamin A deficiency - WHO recommends Vitamin A supplementation in all children with measles to reduce mortality and prevent ocular complications.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as it misses isolation, which is crucial to prevent transmission 

 

Option C. Give MR vaccine + Treat Vit-A deficiency + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as MR vaccine is not indicated during active measles infection

 

Option D. Give aspirin for fever + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as aspirin should be avoided in viral infections in children due to risk of Reye's syndrome

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Management of measles with concurrent Vitamin A deficiency are:

 

  • Isolation
  • Symptomatic treatment 
  • Vitamin A supplementation

choices.text: Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate

questions.text: Why is atropine mixed with diphenoxylate in combination medications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate

 

Diphenoxylate is an opioid used to treat diarrhea by slowing down bowel movements. However, like other opioids, it carries a risk of abuse, especially if taken in large doses. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, is mixed with diphenoxylate in subtherapeutic doses to deter misuse. When taken as prescribed, the amount of atropine is too small to cause significant effects. However, if someone tries to abuse diphenoxylate by taking a large number of tablets, the atropine will also accumulate and cause unpleasant side effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and blurred vision. These side effects are uncomfortable and discourage further abuse of the medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate: This is incorrect because atropine is not added to decrease the adverse effects of diphenoxylate. In fact, when taken in large doses, atropine can add to the side effects rather than diminish them.

 

Option C. To enhance the antidiarrheal effect: While atropine also has anticholinergic properties that can reduce gastrointestinal motility, it is not added for this purpose in the combination. The primary reason for its inclusion is to prevent abuse, not to enhance the antidiarrheal effect.

 

Option D. Atropine produces direct spasmolytic action: Although atropine can reduce spasms in the gastrointestinal tract, it is not included in this combination for its spasmolytic action. The dose of atropine used is subtherapeutic and does not significantly contribute to spasmolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine is added to diphenoxylate to prevent the abuse of the opioid component by causing unpleasant side effects if the medication is taken in large doses, thereby discouraging misuse.

questions.text: A patient presents with infection of the cavernous sinus with involvement of the nerve related on its medial side. To confirm the involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral side

 

The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (away from the midline, or towards the ear). The lateral rectus muscle’s action is essential for lateral gaze. If there is damage to the abducent nerve, the lateral rectus muscle will be paralyzed, leading to an inability to move the eye laterally and resulting in a medial squint (esotropia), where the eye turns inward.

 

To confirm involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards the lateral side. If the nerve is damaged, the patient will be unable to move the eye laterally, confirming the impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior side: Movement of the eye upward (superior gaze) is controlled primarily by the superior rectus muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III). This is not the movement tested for the abducent nerve.

 

Option B. Inferior side: Inferior gaze (looking down) involves the inferior rectus and the superior oblique muscles, innervated by the oculomotor nerve and trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV) respectively. This does not test the abducent nerve.

 

Option C. Medial side: Medial movement of the eye is controlled by the medial rectus muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. This movement is not used to assess the function of the abducent nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) controls the lateral rectus muscle, which moves the eye laterally. Damage to this nerve results in the inability to move the eye outward, leading to a medial squint (esotropia).

 

Mnemonic – EOM3 SO4 LR6 (all extraocular muscle are supplied by 3rd CN except Superior oblique which is supplied by 4th CN and lateral rectus muscle which is supplied by 6th cranial nerve)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used to diagnose Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Brain biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive, and fatal neurological complication of measles infection that typically occurs 7-13 years after the primary infection. The diagnosis of SSPE is based on clinical features and supporting laboratory findings, and brain biopsy can show histopathological features of SSPE (such as demyelination, gliosis, and intranuclear inclusion bodies), it is:

 

  • Invasive
  • Rarely required
  • Not part of the routine diagnostic workup, due to reliable clinical and laboratory alternatives.

     

Dyken's Diagnostic Criteria for SSPE

 

Major Criteria (Need at least 3 for diagnosis):

  1. Characteristic Clinical History and Presentation
    1. Progressive cognitive decline (e.g., intellectual deterioration)
    2. Behavioral changes
    3. Myoclonic jerks (often bilateral and symmetric)
    4. Motor dysfunction or seizures
  2. Characteristic EEG Findings
    1. Periodic, stereotyped, high-voltage discharges occurring every 4–10 seconds (often called "periodic complexes")
  3. Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in CSF
    1. Significantly elevated titers of measles-specific antibodies in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), usually disproportionately high compared to serum
  4. Elevated Measles Antibody Titer in Serum
    1. Measles IgG antibody titer in serum, often >1:256 or equivalent by ELISA
  5. Brain Biopsy or Histopathology
    1. Evidence of panencephalitis with demyelination, inclusion bodies, and gliosis on biopsy or autopsy (usually reserved for unclear cases)
    2. Minor Criteria (Supportive, but not required):
      1. History of primary measles infection, usually before 2 years of age
      2. Presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF
      3. Imaging findings (MRI) showing white matter lesions
      4. Progressive neurological decline over months to years
      5. Response to certain therapies (e.g., intraventricular interferon, isoprinosine)
         

Summary:

 

Diagnosis is typically confirmed if at least 3 of the 5 major criteria are fulfilled, especially with the clinical triad, EEG, and elevated CSF antibodies.

 

Brain biopsy is invasive and rarely needed since the diagnosis can be reliably established with less invasive methods mentioned above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EEG - Incorrect. EEG is a crucial diagnostic tool for SSPE. It typically shows a characteristic pattern with periodic high-amplitude slow-wave complexes that occur every 4-10 seconds, known as Radermecker complexes.

 

Option C. Antibody in CSF - Incorrect. Elevated measles-specific antibodies in CSF are a key diagnostic criterion for SSPE. The CSF shows increased immunoglobulin G (IgG) with oligoclonal bands specific for measles virus.

 

Option D. Antibody in blood - Incorrect. Elevated serum measles antibody titers (typically 1:256 or higher) are an important diagnostic feature of SSPE, reflecting the immune response to persistent measles virus infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SSPE diagnosis relies on clinical features, characteristic EEG patterns, and elevated measles antibodies in both CSF and serum, with brain biopsy being unnecessary for routine diagnosis of this measles complication.

questions.text: Anterior fontanelle closes at which age? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 12-24 months

 

The anterior fontanelle is the largest of the fontanelles in an infant's skull, located at the junction of the frontal and parietal bones. It is diamond-shaped and is clinically significant as it remains open for a period after birth, allowing for the growth of the baby's brain and skull. The closure of the anterior fontanelle typically occurs between 12 to 24 months of age. This is an important developmental milestone and can vary slightly depending on individual growth patterns.

 

 

 

The provided images and discussion indicate that the anterior fontanelle is the last to close among the fontanelles. The posterior fontanelle closes around 3 months, the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle around 6 months, and the posterolateral (mastoid) fontanelle around 12 months. Therefore, the anterior fontanelle, which closes between 12 to 24 months, is correctly identified by option A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 0-3 months: Incorrect. The posterior fontanelle typically closes during this period.

 

Option C. 10-12 months: Incorrect. The fontanelles closing around this age are the posterolateral (mastoid) fontanelles.

 

Option D. 3-6 months: Incorrect. It corresponds to the closure time of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle, not the anterior fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 12 to 24 months of age, making this a key point for assessing normal infant development.

questions.text: In a patient with a left-to-right shunt, the presence of pulmonary plethora, an enlarged left atrium, and a normal aorta suggests which of the following? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)

 

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is characterized by a left-to-right shunt that leads to increased pulmonary blood flow. In VSD, blood shunted from the left ventricle passes through the VSD and is ejected into the pulmonary artery, resulting in pulmonary plethora (increased pulmonary vascularity). The increased blood flow returns to the left atrium, causing left atrial enlargement. The cardiac silhouette in VSD shows a left ventricular type with normal aorta. These findings are classic for VSD - pulmonary plethora, left atrial enlargement, and normal aortic size.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) - In ASD, there is right atrial and right ventricular enlargement with prominent pulmonary artery segments. Left atrial enlargement is typically not seen in isolated ASD as the shunt is pre-tricuspid. The left atrium does not enlarge in size in atrial septal defect unless associated with other anomalies.

 

Option C. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) - In PDA, there would typically be enlargement of the aorta, particularly the ascending aorta and aortic knuckle, along with left atrial and left ventricular enlargement. The ascending aorta and the aortic knuckle are prominently visible on chest X-ray, which contradicts the finding of a normal aorta in the question.

 

Option D. None of the above - This is incorrect because VSD fits the described findings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Ventricular septal defect is characterized by pulmonary plethora, left atrial enlargement, and a normal or small aorta, which distinguishes it from other left-to-right shunts like ASD (which shows RA and RV enlargement) and PDA (which shows aortic enlargement).

questions.text: Which of the following factors is NOT associated with a substantially greater risk of developing epilepsy after febrile seizures? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Family history of Febrile Seizure

 

Family history of febrile seizures is primarily associated with recurrence of febrile seizures rather than development of epilepsy. While it increases the likelihood of having another febrile seizure, it doesn't substantially raise the risk of developing epilepsy. The risk factors table shows that epilepsy risk is 1% after simple febrile seizures, 6% after complex febrile seizures, and much higher (29-33%) with neurodevelopmental abnormalities or family history of epilepsy (18%).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complex Febrile seizures - Complex febrile seizures increase the risk of developing epilepsy to approximately 6%, which is six times higher than with simple febrile seizures.

 

Option C. Developmental Delay - Neurodevelopmental abnormality carries a 33% risk of subsequent epilepsy development, making it one of the strongest risk factors.

 

Option D. Epilepsy in first-degree relatives - Family history of epilepsy increases the risk to approximately 18%, which is significantly higher than the baseline risk.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While family history of febrile seizures increases the risk of recurrence of febrile seizures, it does not substantially increase the risk of developing epilepsy, unlike neurodevelopmental abnormalities, complex febrile seizures, or family history of epilepsy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl, who showed normal development for the first year but now presents with developmental delay and stereotypic hand-wringing movements along with breath-holding spells, is most likely diagnosed with: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Rett's Syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Rett's Syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that almost exclusively affects females and has a characteristic clinical course. The hallmark of Rett's Syndrome is normal development during the first 6-18 months of life followed by developmental regression. The clinical features described in this case are classic for Rett's Syndrome, particularly:

  • Initially normal development followed by regression
  • Stereotypic hand movements, specifically hand-wringing (also described as "hand-washing" movements)
  • Female gender (Rett's syndrome is almost exclusively seen in females)

 

Rett's Syndrome is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene on the X chromosome. Additional features include acquired microcephaly, loss of purposeful hand movements, gait abnormalities, and seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autism - Incorrect. While autism also involves developmental issues, it typically does not follow a period of normal development with subsequent regression. The specific hand-wringing movements are characteristic of Rett's Syndrome rather than autism. Additionally, autism affects both genders, with a higher prevalence in males.

 

Option C. Asperger's Syndrome - Incorrect. Asperger's Syndrome is characterized by normal language development with social communication difficulties and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior. It does not typically present with regression after normal development or the characteristic hand-wringing movements seen in Rett's Syndrome.

 

Option D. Prader-Willi Syndrome - Incorrect. Prader-Willi Syndrome presents with hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy followed by hyperphagia (excessive eating), obesity, and intellectual disability. It does not typically include a period of normal development followed by regression or stereotypic hand movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett's Syndrome presents with normal early development (6-18 months) followed by regression, with characteristic stereotypic hand-wringing movements and is predominantly seen in females due to its X-linked dominant inheritance pattern.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the least common opportunistic fungus known to cause pulmonary infections in children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Sporothrix

 

Explanation:

 

Sporothrix is the least common opportunistic fungus among the given options to cause pulmonary infections in children. Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes sporotrichosis, which is typically a cutaneous infection that follows traumatic inoculation of the fungus into the skin, often through rose thorns or splinters (hence its nickname "rose gardener's disease"). Pulmonary sporotrichosis is extremely rare, especially in children, and is not typically considered among the common opportunistic pulmonary fungal infections.

 

 

The other listed fungi are more commonly associated with pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus fumigatus - Incorrect. Aspergillus is a common cause of opportunistic pulmonary infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with prolonged neutropenia, chronic granulomatous disease, or those on long-term corticosteroid therapy. It can cause invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, and aspergilloma.

 

Option B. Cryptococcus - Incorrect. Cryptococcus (particularly C. neoformans) is a significant cause of pulmonary and central nervous system infections in immunocompromised children, especially those with HIV/AIDS or on immunosuppressive therapy. Pulmonary cryptococcosis is more common than pulmonary sporotrichosis.

 

Option D. Mucor - Incorrect. Mucor species (causing mucormycosis) are increasingly recognized as important opportunistic fungi in immunocompromised children, particularly those with diabetic ketoacidosis, prolonged neutropenia, or those receiving deferoxamine therapy. Rhinocerebral and pulmonary mucormycosis are the most common clinical presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii primarily causes cutaneous sporotrichosis following traumatic inoculation and is rarely associated with pulmonary infections in children, unlike Aspergillus, Cryptococcus, and Mucor species, which are more common opportunistic pulmonary pathogens in immunocompromised pediatric patients.

questions.text: Complete heart block in Neonatal Lupus is associated with which maternal autoantibodies? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Anti-Ro 

 

Explanation: 

 

Complete congenital heart block in neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE) is strongly associated with maternal anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies. These autoantibodies cross the placenta during pregnancy and can affect the developing fetal cardiac conduction system, particularly the atrioventricular (AV) node. The maternal anti-Ro antibodies can cause inflammation and subsequent fibrosis of the fetal cardiac conduction system, resulting in complete heart block. The risk of developing congenital heart block is approximately 2% in anti-Ro positive mothers, but increases to about 15-20% if there is a previous child with neonatal lupus. Anti-La (SSB) antibodies often coexist with anti-Ro and may increase the risk.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Anti-RNP - Incorrect. While anti-RNP antibodies are found in mothers with mixed connective tissue disease and SLE, they are not specifically associated with congenital heart block in neonatal lupus.

 

Option C. Anti-ds-DNA - Incorrect. Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus in mothers but are not the primary antibodies associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Option D. Anti-Sm - Incorrect. Anti-Smith antibodies are highly specific for SLE diagnosis in mothers but are not specifically linked to congenital heart block in neonatal lupus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies are specifically associated with congenital complete heart block in neonatal lupus, requiring careful monitoring of the fetal heart rate during pregnancy in anti-Ro positive mothers, especially those with a previous affected child.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Phenylketonuria (PKU) is NOT true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Excess Melanin

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is characterized by decreased melanin, not excess melanin. PKU is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase that converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. This deficiency leads to increased levels of phenylalanine in the blood and decreased levels of tyrosine. Since tyrosine is a precursor for melanin synthesis, patients with PKU have decreased melanin production, resulting in characteristic physical features including blonde hair, fair skin, and blue eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficient Tyrosine - This is actually correct. In PKU, the body cannot convert phenylalanine to tyrosine due to the enzyme deficiency, resulting in decreased tyrosine levels.

 

Option B. Excess Phenylalanine - This is correct. PKU results in elevated levels of phenylalanine and its metabolites (phenylpyruvate, phenylacetate) due to the enzymatic defect.

 

Option D. Autosomal Recessive - This is correct. PKU follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, requiring mutations in both copies of the phenylalanine hydroxylase gene.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Phenylketonuria results in decreased (not increased) melanin production, leading to characteristic features like fair skin, blonde hair and blue eyes due to reduced tyrosine availability for melanin synthesis.

questions.text: At what age does the kidney typically attain adult-level Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 1-2 years 

 

Explanation: The Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) increases rapidly after birth as the kidneys mature. At birth, the GFR is significantly lower than adult values, typically around 15-20 ml/min/1.73m². During the first few weeks of life, GFR increases dramatically, reaching approximately 50% of adult values by 1-2 weeks of age. By 1-2 years of age, the GFR reaches adult levels of approximately 100-120 ml/min/1.73m². This rapid maturation reflects the postnatal development of renal blood flow, increased filtration surface area, and improved filtration pressure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Birth - Incorrect. At birth, the GFR is only about 15-20% of adult values. The kidneys are still immature with limited filtration capacity, which is why newborns have limited ability to concentrate urine and excrete waste products.

 

Option C. 2-5 years - Incorrect. This is too late, as adult levels of GFR are already achieved by 1-2 years of age. By 2-5 years, kidney function has been at adult levels for some time.

 

Option D. Puberty - Incorrect. This is much too late. Adult-level GFR is reached many years before puberty. At puberty, the kidneys have long been functioning at adult capacity in terms of filtration rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal function matures rapidly during infancy, with GFR reaching adult levels by 1-2 years of age.

choices.text: Rabies vaccine + Immunoglobulin + Wound management

questions.text: Management of an HIV-positive patient with multiple punctured wound bites caused by a dog is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rabies vaccine + Immunoglobulin + Wound management

 

Multiple punctured wounds classify as Class III bite according to WHO classification. For Class III bites, the standard protocol includes:

 

  • Wound management - washing with running water and soap for 15-20 minutes
  • Local antiseptics if there isn't much bleeding
  • Avoid suturing
  • Administration of both rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin due to severity of exposure The HIV status of the patient doesn't alter this protocol.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Only wound management: Incorrect because Class III bites require comprehensive management including both immunological interventions along with wound care.

 

Option B. Rabies vaccine + Wound management: Incorrect because Class III bites require immunoglobulin in addition to vaccine and wound management.

 

Option D. Immunoglobulin + Wound management: Incorrect because rabies vaccine is essential component of post-exposure prophylaxis and cannot be omitted.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Class III rabies exposure (multiple punctured wounds) requires complete post-exposure prophylaxis including:

 

  • Local wound management
  • Rabies vaccine
  • Rabies immunoglobulin regardless of patient's immune status.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use is admitted to the hospital. He presents with anxiety, tremors, and agitation after his last drink 24 hours ago. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for control of alcohol withdrawal symptoms? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, a class of medications that act as central nervous system depressants, similar to alcohol. In cases of alcohol withdrawal, benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment because they help alleviate symptoms by enhancing GABAergic activity, which is reduced during alcohol withdrawal. This helps to stabilize the central nervous system, reducing anxiety, tremors, and agitation.

 

Among benzodiazepines, lorazepam is preferred, especially in patients with liver disease, because it does not undergo hepatic metabolism to active metabolites, making it safer in individuals with compromised liver function.

 

Other benzodiazepines such as chlordiazepoxide or diazepam may also be used, but lorazepam is often chosen in clinical scenarios where hepatic function is a concern.

 

Other sympatholytic drugs to manage withdrawal symptoms  – Beta blockers; Clonidine and Lofexidine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning. It is not indicated for the treatment of alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Disulfiram: Disulfiram is used as a deterrent in alcohol dependence by causing an unpleasant reaction when alcohol is consumed. However, it is not used to manage withdrawal symptoms and is contraindicated in acute alcohol withdrawal.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic that is used to treat generalized anxiety disorder. It is not effective in managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms and does not have the CNS depressant properties needed to alleviate withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:         

 

Lorazepam is the most appropriate medication for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms due to its CNS depressant effects and safety profile, particularly in patients with liver impairment.

questions.text: A tourist group was headed by a tour guide. They were seen many times in an area. Which kind of group dynamics does this represent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herd

 

A herd is a group of people with a leader whom they follow without questioning - like a political party leader being followed by party workers. In this case, the tourist group follows their tour guide without questioning, making it a classic example of herd behavior.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Crowd: Incorrect because a crowd is a temporary gathering of people who come together due to common interest without any leader or organization, like people gathering to watch a cricket match.

 

Option B. Band: Incorrect because a band is a community comprised of groups of families who not only live together but follow a certain pattern of life and culture.

 

Option D. Mob: Incorrect because while a mob has a leader, it is highly emotional, unstable, disorganized and sometimes acts against the law.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Following an accident, a patient presented with an inability to flex the MCP joint and extend the IP joint of his hand. Which nerve is damaged here? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve

 

The patient’s symptoms of being unable to flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extend the interphalangeal (IP) joints suggest a problem with the lumbrical muscles. The lumbricals are responsible for these movements. Specifically, the third and fourth lumbrical muscles, which flex the MCP joints and extend the IP joints of the ring and little fingers, are innervated by the ulnar nerve. Damage to the ulnar nerve can result in a condition known as "claw hand," where these functions are compromised, leading to the inability to perform the described movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve primarily controls the extension of the wrist and fingers, but not the flexion of the MCP joints or extension of the IP joints. Hence, it is not involved in this condition.

 

Option B. Anterior interosseous nerve: This is a branch of the median nerve, primarily responsible for the motor function of some of the deep muscles in the forearm but does not innervate the lumbricals. Therefore, it is not responsible for the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve: This nerve innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm, responsible for elbow flexion, but it does not play a role in the movement of the fingers or hand. Therefore, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar nerve is responsible for innervating the third and fourth lumbricals, which are essential for flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints. Damage to this nerve can lead to the characteristic "claw hand" deformity.

questions.text: What is the preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Upper end of the tibia

 

Explanation:

 

The preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants is the upper end (proximal portion) of the tibia, specifically the anteromedial surface of the proximal tibial metaphysis, approximately 1-2 cm below the tibial tuberosity. This site is preferred in infants because:

  • It is easily accessible and has minimal overlying soft tissue
  • The cortex is relatively thin, making penetration easier
  • It is distant from vital structures like the heart and lungs
  • The proximal tibial growth plate does not close until later in childhood
  • It allows stable positioning of the infant during the procedure

 

In infants under 12-18 months of age, the tibial marrow cavity is still highly cellular and provides adequate samples for diagnostic purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sternum - Incorrect. The sternum is not recommended as a site for bone marrow aspiration in infants due to the risk of serious complications, particularly cardiac or great vessel puncture. The sternum is too thin in infants and the proximity to vital structures makes this site dangerous.

 

Option B. Spinous process of lumbar vertebra - Incorrect. The spinous processes of vertebrae are not used for bone marrow aspiration at any age. This site would be both technically difficult and dangerous due to proximity to the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Lower end of femur - Incorrect. While the distal femur can be used as an alternative site for bone marrow aspiration in infants, it is not the preferred first-line site. The proximal tibia offers better access and is generally easier to perform.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The upper end of the tibia is the preferred site for bone marrow aspiration in infants under 12-18 months of age due to its accessibility, thinner cortex, distance from vital structures, and adequate cellularity.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive

 

The graph shown is a Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is a double reciprocal plot commonly used to illustrate enzyme kinetics. In this plot, the x-axis represents the reciprocal of the substrate concentration (1/[S]), and the y-axis represents the reciprocal of the reaction velocity (1/V). The graph is particularly useful in distinguishing different types of enzyme inhibition.

 

In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This type of inhibition is characterized by an increase in the apparent Km (Michaelis constant), which is reflected as a change in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged because the effect of the inhibitor can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration.

 

In the Lineweaver-Burk plot, this is depicted as the two lines (with and without inhibitor) crossing at the y-axis. The y-intercept remains the same (indicating unchanged Vmax), but the slope changes due to the increase in apparent Km, which shifts the x-intercept closer to the origin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds to a different site on the enzyme, not the active site. This binding reduces the overall number of active enzyme molecules, thereby decreasing Vmax without affecting Km. In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, this results in lines that intersect on the x-axis, not the y-axis.

 

 

Option C. Un-competitive: Un-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This results in parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, as both Km and Vmax decrease.

 

 

Option D. Allosteric: Allosteric inhibition involves the binding of an inhibitor to a site other than the active site, leading to changes in enzyme activity. This type of inhibition is more complex and isn't typically represented by a Lineweaver-Burk plot in the same way competitive, non-competitive, or un-competitive inhibitions are.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In competitive inhibition, the Lineweaver-Burk plot shows lines that cross at the y-axis, indicating that Vmax remains unchanged while Km increases due to the competition between the inhibitor and the substrate for the enzyme's active site.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines was withdrawn due to an increased risk of intussusception? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Rotavirus Vaccine 

 

Explanation: 

 

The first licensed rotavirus vaccine (RotaShield) was withdrawn from the market in 1999 due to an increased risk of intussusception. Intussusception is a condition where one segment of intestine telescopes into another segment, causing intestinal obstruction. The original RotaShield vaccine showed an association with intussusception at a rate of approximately 1 case per 10,000 vaccinated infants, with most cases occurring within 1 week of the first dose. This led to its voluntary withdrawal. Newer rotavirus vaccines (RotaTeq and Rotarix) were subsequently developed and have a much lower risk of intussusception (approximately 1-5 cases per 100,000 vaccinated infants).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. MMR (Measles, Mumps, and Rubella) - Incorrect. The MMR vaccine has never been withdrawn from the market. While it has faced controversy due to a now-retracted publication suggesting a link to autism, this claim has been thoroughly disproven by multiple large studies, and MMR remains an essential component of childhood immunization programs.

 

Option C. JE Vaccine (Japanese Encephalitis) - Incorrect. The JE vaccine has not been withdrawn due to intussusception. Some older versions had higher rates of adverse effects, but these were primarily allergic reactions, not intussusception.

 

Option D. Polio Vaccine - Incorrect. The oral polio vaccine (OPV) has been replaced by the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) in many countries, but this was due to the rare risk of vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP), not intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The original rotavirus vaccine (RotaShield) was withdrawn due to an increased risk of intussusception.
